DOC.HEAD: Romania Seeking Swiss Help to Recover Any Ceausescu Assets
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Romania's provisional governmment will ask Switzerland for judicial assistance to try to recover any assets Nicolae Ceausescu may have stashed in Swiss banks before he was ousted and executed. Ambassador Gheorghe Dolgu, who declared his support for the anti-Ceausescu uprising last week, delivered a diplomatic note to the Swiss Justice Ministry on Wednesday announcing that a formal request would follow. The new leadership has two months to detail its request. In anticipation of the request, Switzerland on Sunday froze an any assets linked to Ceausescu or his clan, addressing itself in particular to two of its largest banks, Credit Suisse and Union Bank of Switzerland. The action was taken after Moritz Leuenberger, a Social Democratic member of parliament and lawyer, said he received information from unidentified Romanian exile sources that Ceausescu had transferred about $400 million, chiefly gold bullion, to Zurich, much of it in recent weeks and months. Justice Ministry spokesman Joerg Kistler said a circular from the Romanian National Bank dated Dec. 25 asked all countries to block any Ceausescu accounts they may be spotted. According to a videotape of his secret trial released by the new leadership in Bucharest, Ceausescu denied having assets in Switzerland and refused to sign a statement authorizing the return of any such assets to the Romanian National Bank. His wife, Elena, rejected the military court's question about Swiss funds as a provocation. In Zurich, Union Bank spokeswoman Gertrud Erismann said the freeze had been ``superfluous because no serious bank would permit in such a situation permit the withdrawal of funds by people who may have obtained them illegally.'' She declined comment when asked whether Union Bank had traced any funds. Confirming or denying their existence would violate Swiss banking secrecy laws, she added. A Credit Suisse spokesman, Helmut Reinke, said a careful check had not produced any evidence of Ceausescu-linked assets at the bank.
